description.narrative:
Water is life: building thriving communities in rural niger Niger is the lowest ranking county on the human development index and suffers from chronic poverty, extreme weather conditions, such as drought, and the long-term impact of conflict. Only onein two people living in rural Niger have access to safe drinking water. This is largely due to the severe lack of adequate water infrastructureto support the population’s needs. This is because the government focuses on funding urban rather than rural areas. Any infrastructure that does exist has a low level of functionality (13.85% in Tillabéry and 8.09% in Zinder). This is largely due to the low capacity of local technical services to repair and optimize existing water points due to a lack of fundingand knowledge. The limited number of repair men that are available to service the water points face shortages of the spare parts necessary for pump maintenance. This is due to less investment in the poorest, most marginalised areas, and on-going issues with the spare parts supply chain. This lack of water and sanitation facilities has a knock-on effect on people’s health, education and livelihoods. In rural Niger: • Women and girls walk daily, up to 8kms, to access water from traditional water sources, and rivers that do not meet acceptable standards for drinking water.
• Child mortality (under 5s) stands at 8.4%, twenty times higher than the UK, and this is partially due to preventable, diarrhoeal diseases spread through a lack of awareness of good hygiene practices and no access to clean water.
• Open air defection and a lack of best practice regarding handwashing, for example using soap, are commonplace, leading to the spread of disease such as COVID-19 .
• 75% of the rural population has not attended school or received any level of education, partially due to theburden of domestic responsibilities such as collecting water which tends to be located far from households
• Men are often absent,as they travel to other regions to find work, leaving women-headed households that rely on market gardening for food for their family and to sell at the local market. Without access to water they cannot grow crops critical to their nutrition and their ability to make an income.

participating-org.narrative: DEMI-E is a Nigerien NGO recognized by decree N°405/MI/AT/DAPJ/SA of October 28, 1998. Its head office is located in Zinder with representations in the regions of Diffa, Tillabéry, Tahoua, Maradi and Niamey. Its governance is structured around three mainbodies namely the General Assembly (GA) which is the supreme body of the organization, the Board of Directors (BOD) which is the management body of DEMI-E and the Executive Secretariat which is the executive body of DEMI-E as summarized in the following organization chart:The organizational model defined by the NGO responds to the following issues: - How to reach a maximum of beneficiaries? - How to improve the impact and effectiveness of interventions?- How to optimize the geographical coverage of the NGO?Our vision: ''DEMI-E aspires to a world where everyone participates voluntarily, equitably and inclusively in the sustainable well-being of communities''.Ourmission: DEMI-E's mission is to ''Contribute to the strengthening of the resilience capacitiesof rural and urban communities through the implementation of self-managed development initiatives''. Our intervention strategy : DEMI-E's intervention strategy is based on its strategic planning, internal policies and procedures and takes into account national development orientations (3N Initiative,PDES, etc.). It is essentially based on the needs of the populations. The NGO DEMI-E wants to listen to the Nigerien population, through the needs expressed by the villages, communes, associations and groups. It wants to be proactive by proposing initiatives, by defining projects jointly with the service seekers. The NGO DEMI-E develops itself taking into account the socio-economic environment of Niger, it adapts to the constraints of the environment, structural changes, technological evolution, new communication systems.Translated with www.DeepL.com/Translator (free version)
